titleStmt.title: M112, Set 2 of 3 [The Reader: must in order to sit and stand there, while the sun beats...]. Typescript fragment, unsigned and undated with the author's ms. additions. 2 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M112, Set 2 of 3 [The Reader: must in order to sit and stand there, while the sun beats...]. Typescript fragment, unsigned and undated with the author's ms. additions. 2 fols.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
must in order to sit and stand there, while the sun beats
or the rain pours have some strong inducement; something
that puzzles; and then concludes. They must have love;
murder; adultery. And this contribution (contrbution) of the audience
was more unfortunate to the dramatist than (tahn) to the lyric
singer. Often the actions is too violent for the words.
There is a dislocation between the thought and the action.
No one feels what is said. The emotion is often
plastered (las ered) on to a dumb figure. But if violence rapidity
movement are dictated by the audience an inevitable confusion (confusin)
follows. On the other hand the playwright
like the singer has an anomymous vitality,
drawn from (fro) other bodies, a perennial (pe renniel) common vigour.
Nor is dead (dad) in ourselves. The crude early dramas (ddrams)
have still the power to make us ask--as the audience asked--
the childs question (questin): what comes next? a power denied to [20th?] century [illeg.]
So we become ourselves (ourelves) anonymous in the early plays.

It is only later when the pressure of silent hoarded (horaded)
emotion had thrown up words, as the fingers (fi gers) of the man at the
casts letters from the bubbling lead,
that we lose this general quality to gain---
everything it seems. For the curtain (curatin) goes on rising
incessantly for fifty years. Now it rises on ;
then on ; on ;
on ; finally on . By (Byt) that time the sxxgxx
play has outgrown the stage. The stage has become too small
to act this drama. Perhaps after centuries (cnuries), the play will
come to birth again, differently, in ,
in . But the play never again fitted the stage

completely in England. The book after takes the
place of the play. And Anon is dead for ever.
